p.s: Many experienced speakers use rhetorical devices to more succesfullysuccessfully convince the audience, they're right.
In the following, it will be analyzed how Barack Obama used them in his 2007 speech in Bettendorf, Iowa to convince his audience that the American dreamDream is worth fighting for.
He starts off by establishing a connection to his audience using a fun metaphor, saying he grew up just a stone's throw from their town and saying he shares a lot with them.
This makes him feel more relatable and the locals automatically want to hear more from him, even before he said anything political.

The next part uses several negatively connotated phrases (division l. 9, separated l. 5), pointing out the idea that Americans are divided by race, religion etc. Obama deliberately mentions Washington as a place where these ideas originate to automatically distance the coceptsconcepts from the people in Iowa.
He follows up these divisions with his antithesis - after travelling around America, he's been more impressed by the values and hopes we share he says.
This is followed by an enumeration of contrasts like men and women, young and old that, disregarding their differences, still share the same dreams.
The enumeration also creates a parallelism to the enumeration of divisions in the paragraph before.
The paragraph finishes by climaxing the apparent dreams and wishes he encountered - and incidentally also supports in his presidential campaign - to the concept of the American Dream (l. 12).
Next up, Obama connects these dreams to himself, specifically mentioning government support while retelling his grandparent's life.
He concidentallycoincidentally also mentions government support during his sister's life, creating a link to his campaign having to give more government support to poor people.
This paragraph also repeats the formulation no matter before listing factors that Washington says divide the people (l. 15f.) to create a feeling of equality.
Finally, Obama explains how he fought for American Dreams in the past.
In this part, a lot of personal pronouns for himself (me, I) are used to finally put a focus on himself.

Another metaphor (forgotten corner, dream was slipping away) comes up, signifying the danger the American Dream is in, and concluding that the dreams of the people are worth fighting for and that he knows it.

All in all, this speech is filled to the brim with rhetorical devices like climaxes, enumerations and Anaphorasanaphoras, all used to firstly convince his audience that Americans have good dreams that are worth fighting for and secondly, that Barack Obama is the president to do it.
